messages.text:
Like this:
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lebesgue%27s_decomposition_theorem>

attachments.title: Lebesgue's decomposition theorem
attachments.text:
In mathematics, more precisely in measure theory, Lebesgue's decomposition theorem states that for every two σ-finite signed measures 
  
    
      
        μ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \mu }
   and 
  
    
      
        ν
      
    
    {\displaystyle \nu }
   on a measurable space 
  
    
      
        (
        Ω
        ,
        Σ
        )
        ,
      
    
    {\displaystyle (\Omega ,\Sigma ),}
    there exist two σ-finite signed measures 
  
    
      
        
          ν
          
            0
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \nu _{0}}
   and 
  
    
      
        
          ν
          
            1
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \nu _{1}}
   such that:

  
    
      
        ν
        =
        
          ν
          
            0
          
        
        +
        
          ν
          
            1
          
        
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \nu =\nu _{0}+\nu _{1}\,}
  

  
    
      
        
          ν
          
            0
          
        
        ≪
        μ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \nu _{0}\ll \mu }
   (that is, 
  
    
      
        
          ν
          
            0
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \nu _{0}}
   is absolutely continuous with respect to 
  
    
      
        μ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \mu }
  )

  
    
      
        
          ν
          
            1
          
        
        ⊥
        μ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \nu _{1}\perp \mu }
   (that is, 
  
    
      
        
          ν
          
            1
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \nu _{1}}
   and 
  
    
      
        μ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \mu }
   are singular).These two measures are uniquely determined by 
  
    
      
        μ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \mu }
   and 
  
    
      
        ν
      
    
    {\displaystyle \nu }
  .

messages.text: Are you starting from the densities? If so I guess you have to do quadrature or MC. If you start from the cdf it’s quite easy to find the measure in a hyper-rectangular set using the H-volume. You could then find it for any arbitrary set by discretizating it into boxes

elements.text: Are you starting from the densities? If so I guess you have to do quadrature or MC. If you start from the cdf it’s quite easy to find the measure in a hyper-rectangular set using the H-volume. You could then find it for any arbitrary set by discretizating it into boxes

messages.text: <https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/252525/does-anyone-know-what-the-intuition-of-h-volume-is>

attachments.title: Does anyone know what the intuition of H-volume is?
attachments.text: For a 2-place real function $H$, H-volume of $[x_1,x_2]\times[y_1,y_2]$ is $H(x_2,y_2)-H(x_2,y_1)-H(x_1,y_2)+H(x_1,y_1)$. What is really the intuition of the H-volume?
attachments.fallback: Cross Validated: Does anyone know what the intuition of H-volume is?

attachments.title: LAFI 2021 - POPL 2021
attachments.text: Inference concerns re-calibrating program parameters based on observed data, and has gained wide traction in machine learning and data science. Inference can be driven by probabilistic analysis and simulation, and through back-propagation and differentiation. Languages for inference offer built-in support for expressing probabilistic models and inference methods as programs, to ease reasoning, use, and reuse. The recent rise of practical implementations as well as research activity in inference-based programming has renewed the need for semantics to help us share insights and innovations. ...

messages.text:
Playing with parameterizations
```julia> @btime logdensity(Bernoulli(p = logistic(2.0)), 1)
  1.152 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
-0.12692801104297252

julia> @btime logdensity(Bernoulli(logit_p = 2.0), 1)
  1.152 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
-0.1269280110429727

julia> @btime logdensity(Bernoulli(p = logistic(20.0)), 1)
  1.152 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
-2.0611535832696244e-9

julia> @btime logdensity(Bernoulli(logit_p = 20.0), 1)
  0.010 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
-2.061153026033935e-9```
